div.p: The person, place, event, condition, other statement that this statement addresses or belongs to. For an existential finding, the Subject is the 'owner' of the object said to exist or not exist. For example, the subject for a condition is a patient; the subject for wound size is a wound. Subjects are themselves statements.

publisher.value: HL7 Patient Care and Clinical Information Modeling Initiative Work Groups

description.value: The person, place, event, condition, other statement that this statement addresses or belongs to. For an existential finding, the Subject is the 'owner' of the object said to exist or not exist. For example, the subject for a condition is a patient; the subject for wound size is a wound. Subjects are themselves statements.

definition.value: The person, place, event, condition, other statement that this statement addresses or belongs to. For an existential finding, the Subject is the 'owner' of the object said to exist or not exist. For example, the subject for a condition is a patient; the subject for wound size is a wound. Subjects are themselves statements.

human.value: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

definition.value: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

short.value: identifies the meaning of the extension

definition.value: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.

comment.value: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition SHALL be a URI for the Structure Definition defining the extension.

definition.value: Value of extension - may be a resource or one of a constrained set of the data types (see Extensibility in the spec for list).

The person, place, event, condition, other statement that this statement addresses or belongs to. For an existential finding, the Subject is the 'owner' of the object said to exist or not exist. For example, the subject for a condition is a patient; the subject for wound size is a wound. Subjects are themselves statements.
